title: Navigation bar
description: Navigation bars offer a persistent and convenient way to switch between primary destinations in an app.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There's one type of navigation bar in Material. In M2, this component is named bottom navigation.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 4 destinations using icons and text labels

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)
Available
M2 guideline – Bottom navigationAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• The position of the navigation bar makes primary user journeys easy to access on mobile devices
  • Items in the navigation bar remain consistent in their destination assignment, placement, and interaction behavior across an app
  • Navigation items should be relatively equal in importance
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Elevation: No shadow
  • Layout: Container height is taller
  • States: The active destination can be indicated with a pill shape in a contrasting color
  • Name: Bottom navigation has been renamed “navigation bar”

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 3 destinations and contrasting color shape identifying the active state

contentChunks.footer: M2: The navigation bar is positioned above page content, as indicated by a drop shadow. Filled and regular weight icons indicate active states; regular outline icons indicate inactive states.
contentChunks.altText: M2 navigation bar with 1 filled icon showing the active state and 3 outlined icons showing inactive state.

contentChunks.footer: M3: Active states are represented with filled icons and a contrasting pill-shaped active indicator, while inactive states are represented with outlined icons. The height of the navigation bar is taller.
contentChunks.altText: M3 navigation bar with 1 filled icon surrounded by a pill shape in contrasting color to show the active state and 3 outlined icons showing inactive states.

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 1 active destination and 3 inactive destinations with labels and icons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Navigation bars (nav bars) provide access to three to five destinations.

The nav bar is positioned at the bottom of screens for convenient access. Each destination is represented by an icon and optional text label.

When a navigation bar icon is tapped or focused, the user is taken to the navigation destination associated with that icon.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar with 5 destinations
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar showing 5 destinations featuring icons and text labels, with 1 active destination

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Navigation bars should be used for:

  • Top-level destinations that need to be accessible from anywhere in the app
  • Three to five destinations
  • Mobile or tablet only

Navigation bars shouldn’t be used for:

  • Single tasks, such as viewing a single email
  • User preferences or settings

contentChunks.footer: On mobile or tablet, navigation bars should be used for top-level destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar showing 5 destinations featuring icons and labels, with 1 active destination

contentChunks.footer: Use a navigation bar for destinations that should remain easy to access throughout a user journey.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 4 destinations with icon and text label, 1 active destination.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use more than five destinations. When elements are placed close to each other, translated text length and element collision can cause problems. For more than 5 destinations, consider using tabs or a navigation drawer.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar showing 6 destinations placed too close together

contentChunks.footer: Use caution if icons are displayed without labels. Icon meaning should always be unambiguous and accessible for all users. Text labels can be omitted in specific circumstances where reduced visual impact is necessary.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 4 destinations with only icons, no labels

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a navigation bar for fewer than three destinations. Instead, use tabs.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar featuring only 2 destinations

contentChunks.footer: Combining navigation bars and tabs may cause confusion, as their relationship to the content may be unclear. Tabs share a common subject, whereas navigation bar destinations are top-level and disconnected from each other.
contentChunks.altText: App screen with tabs on top and navigation bar on bottom, both with active destinations

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar destinations have fixed positions. They don’t scroll or move horizontally.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with scrolling destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Icon
3. Label text
4. Active indicator
5. Large badge (optional)
6. Small badge (optional)
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 6 elements of navigation bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Navigation bar containers hold all elements making up a destination, including icon, label text, and active indicator.

contentChunks.footer: The navigation bar container holds all elements.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram showing navigation bar container with elements

contentChunks.htmlValue: The container is divided into equal-width columns, one for each destination. The width of each destination can be calculated by taking the width of the navigation bar and dividing it by the number of destinations.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar divided into equal-width columns.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of container with 4 equal-width columns for destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue: The container can have a color fill to provide separation from the content behind it.

contentChunks.footer: If there’s no conflicting content behind the navigation bar, the navigation bar can be the same color as the background.
contentChunks.altText: Same-color navigation bar and background

contentChunks.footer: A color-filled navigation bar provides separation from content scrolling behind it.
contentChunks.altText: Content separated by color-filled navigation bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icons

Destinations in navigation bars always include an icon. It’s best to pair icons with text labels, especially if the icon doesn’t have obvious meaning.

Use a filled icon for the active destination and outlined icons for inactive destinations.

contentChunks.footer: If a filled version of an icon is unavailable, consider showing label text only for the active destination to provide a secondary cue.
contentChunks.altText: Label text shown for all destinations

contentChunks.footer: When filled and outlined icon styles are available, use outlined icons to represent inactive destinations and filled icons for the active destination.
contentChunks.altText: Outlined icons and filled icons representing destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue: Active and inactive icons should have sufficient contrast with the container.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use multiple or low-contrast colors in a navigation bar, as they make it harder for users to distinguish the active item and navigate to other destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 5 destinations, each a different color

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Active indicator

The active indicator is a background shape communicating which destination of the navigation bar is currently being displayed.

contentChunks.footer: Use the active indicator only for the active destination.
contentChunks.altText: Active indicator communicating navigation bar active destination

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use the active indicator for more than one destination at a time.
contentChunks.altText: 3 active indicators used for 3 destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue: Upon selection of a destination, the active indicator visually expands behind its icon. This transformation is limited to one axis during the shape expansion.

contentChunks.footer: Animate the shape expansion along 1 axis to preserve the sense of a flat, shared plane.
contentChunks.altText: Active indicator expands along 1 axis

contentChunks.footer: Don’t animate the shape expansion uniformly.
contentChunks.altText: Active indicator expands uniformly behind  icon

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Label text provides short, meaningful descriptions of navigation bar destinations.

It’s possible to show only the label of the active destination.

The active destination icon and label are centered while the inactive destinations have a centered icon

Label text in navigation bars uses the overline style. Label text should have sufficient contrast with the container.

contentChunks.footer: Label text provides short descriptions of destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar showing 4 destinations, with 1 active destination featuring both icon and text label

contentChunks.footer: Use brief text labels to identify the purpose of a destination.
contentChunks.altText: Label text label identifying destination purpose.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t wrap or truncate text as it can make the label hard to understand.
contentChunks.altText: Truncated label text in navigation bar

contentChunks.footer: Don’t shrink longer text to fit on a single line.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar showing shrunk label text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Badges (optional)

Icons in navigation bars can display badges in their upper right corners. 

Badges can contain dynamic information, such as the number of new messages.

contentChunks.footer: A small badge uses only shape to indicate a status change or new notification.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with with 3 icons, 1 with small round badge

contentChunks.footer: A large badge displays a number within a container to indicate a quantifiable status change related to a destination.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 3 icons, 1 with large badge displaying number in container

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement
Navigation bars can be paired with a floating action button (FAB).

contentChunks.footer: The FAB can be right-aligned above the navigation bar.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with FAB aligned right.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t indent the FAB off-center of the device width; don’t indent the FAB if there are an odd number of destinations. Instead, center an indented FAB between two or four destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Off-centered FAB set between background and navigation bar

contentChunks.htmlValue: Navigation bars can be temporarily covered by dialogs, bottom sheets, navigation drawers, the on-screen keyboard, or other elements needed to complete a flow. They should not be permanently obstructed on any screen.

contentChunks.footer: The search feature of the “Radio” screen triggers the on-screen keyboard, temporarily covering the bottom navigation bar until the search flow is completed.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar covered by on-screen keyboard

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

Only use navigation bars on mobile and small tablet interfaces. On large screens, swap out navigation bars for a component that’s better suited to large screen contexts, such as a navigation rail or navigation drawer.

At medium breakpoints, replace the navigation bar with a navigation rail.

At large breakpoints, replace the navigation rail with a navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bars are best suited for mobile and small tablet interfaces.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 4 destinations on mobile/small tablet

contentChunks.footer:
Small breakpoints: 360-599dp
For small devices like phones, horizontal space is at a premium; the content area of an app usually spans the entire width of a screen. In this case, smaller navigation components should anchor to the top or bottom of a layout, saving space while making primary destinations accessible.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar on small screen

contentChunks.footer:
Medium breakpoints: 600-1239dp 
On medium-sized devices like tablets, move primary navigation elements into a navigation rail that is fixed to the leading edge of the layout.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail on tablet screen

contentChunks.footer:
Large breakpoints: 1240dp+ 
On devices with 1240dp+ widths, present destinations in a permanently visible or dismissible navigation drawer. Assign hierarchy based on how frequently or quickly a user needs to move between destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer open on desktop screen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Mobile and tablet

The navigation bar container uses 100% of the screen width on mobile and tablet breakpoints.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bars use 100% of the screen width.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 3 destinations using full screen width

contentChunks.htmlValue: On tablet- and landscape-oriented mobile screens, navigation bar destinations can retain the same spacing used in portrait mode, or be equally distributed across the container.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom navigation bar in landscape view with destinations keeping the same spacing as in portrait mode.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar in landscape view with destinations keeping the same spacing as in portrait mode.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Desktop

The navigation bar is designed for smaller screens. It’s not intended for desktop.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use navigation bars for desktop layouts. Instead, use a navigation rail or tabs.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar in desktop layout, with 4 destinations spread out

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density 

Always use the default height for navigation bars as a minimum.

contentChunks.footer: Keep navigation bars the default height.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 3 destinations, 1 active, set at default height

contentChunks.footer: Don’t apply density to navigation bars.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with applied density showing 3 destinations, 1 active

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Navigation

When you select a navigation bar item (one that’s not currently selected), the app navigates to that destination’s screen using a top level transition pattern.

After selection, destinations can behave in one of two ways:

  1. Preserve state: If the user previously interacted with this destination, it returns to that place on the screen, including scroll position, tab selection, and in-line search.

  2. Reset state: Any prior user interactions and temporary screen states are reset, including scroll position, tab selection, and in-line search.

Choose the behavior that best suits the product and user needs. For example, an app that requires frequent switching between sections should preserve each section’s state.

contentChunks.footer: After selecting an item on the bottom navigation bar, the app navigates to that destination’s screen.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 4 destinations, 1 selected, moving from selection to chosen screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Re-selecting the currently active destination resets the scroll position to the top of the page.

contentChunks.footer: Selecting the already selected navigation item returns you to the top of the screen
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar with 4 destinations, 1 selected, moving from selection to chosen screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: When moving downward in the app’s hierarchy (from a parent screen to a child screen), a navigation bar can be displayed persistently for quick navigation between an app’s sections.

contentChunks.footer: The navigation bar in this music app remains in view when navigating to an album.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar displayed consistently across app destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

Upon scroll, the navigation bar can appear or disappear.

contentChunks.footer: Scrolling downward can hide the navigation bar; scrolling upward reveals it.
contentChunks.altText: Scrolling can reveal or hide a navigation bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Selection

The icon becomes filled and the active indicator expands from the center of the icon when switching between destinations.

contentChunks.footer: The active indicator expands from the target when a destination is selected.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar transitioning when destination is tapped

contentChunks.htmlValue: When a destination is tapped, the destination screens use a top level transition pattern. In addition, the icon becomes filled and the active indicator expands from the center of the icon.

contentChunks.footer: Tapping a destination allows for several transitions to occur.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Don't use swipe

Swiping across the navigation bar does not navigate between destinations. Swipe behavior should be reserved for related items, such as cards in a carousel, or actions such as archiving a list item.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t allow people to change destinations with a swipe gesture.
Allow people to change destinations through selection.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Transitions

Use a fade-through transition pattern for movement between navigation bar destinations.

Lateral (side-to-side) transitions can imply a peer relationship between the items that risks misleading users to believe gestural navigation is available.

contentChunks.footer: Signal transitions between active and inactive destinations with the shape expansion.
contentChunks.altText: Fade-through transition pattern between navigation bar destinations

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a lateral motion to transition between views. Lateral motion is reserved for navigating between peers.
contentChunks.altText: Side-to-side transition implying peer relationship

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
